source_payload.html:
Adjusted

← Previous revision Revision as of 19:47, 7 February 2026
Line 7: Line 7:
Nine years later, John Hick Jr as he is referred to at the time, was awarded the silver medal by the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] for his novel invention of an expanding [[mandrel]] for turning [[lathes]], it was an adaptation of a principle developed by [[Marc Brunel]] for [[pulley]] [[Block (sailing)|block]] manufacture at [[Portsmouth Block Mills|Portsmouth]] and received the praise of three eminent engineers; [[Bryan Donkin]], [[Joshua Field (engineer)|Joshua Field]] and [[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]].<ref name='Mandrel'>{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=No. XI. Expanding Mandrel|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1839|volume=LIII|pages=87–92|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326867/41326867#page/n1/mode/2up|access-date=13 November 2015|location=Jstor}}</ref> He was a member of the [[National Society for Promoting Religious Education|National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church in England and Wales]] in 1841.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Thirtieth Annual Report of the National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church Throughout England and Wales | title=Thirtieth Annual Report |date=1841|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_LYEAAAAQAAJ|access-date=26 November 2015|location=Oxford University}}</ref>
Nine years later, John Hick Jr as he is referred to at the time, was awarded the silver medal by the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] for his novel invention of an expanding [[mandrel]] for turning [[lathes]], it was an adaptation of a principle developed by [[Marc Brunel]] for [[pulley]] [[Block (sailing)|block]] manufacture at [[Portsmouth Block Mills|Portsmouth]] and received the praise of three eminent engineers; [[Bryan Donkin]], [[Joshua Field (engineer)|Joshua Field]] and [[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]].<ref name='Mandrel'>{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=No. XI. Expanding Mandrel|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1839|volume=LIII|pages=87–92|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326867/41326867#page/n1/mode/2up|access-date=13 November 2015|location=Jstor}}</ref> He was a member of the [[National Society for Promoting Religious Education|National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church in England and Wales]] in 1841.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Thirtieth Annual Report of the National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church Throughout England and Wales | title=Thirtieth Annual Report |date=1841|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_LYEAAAAQAAJ|access-date=26 November 2015|location=Oxford University}}</ref>


During 1842, Hick was awarded a second silver medal by the Society of Arts for his invention of an [[Ellipsograph]]; conceived in 1840,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Elliptograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton|url=https://collection.sciencemuseum.org.uk/objects/co60100/elliptograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolto-curve-drawing-instruments-ellipsographs|website=Science Museum Group|access-date=10 November 2016|date=1840}}</ref> the device provided a simple and accurate solution for the drawing ''[[ellipse|ellipsoid forms]]'' of various proportions. Hick received further praise from [[James Nasmyth]], [[William Fairbairn]], [[Joseph Whitworth]], and amongst others, [[Charles Holtzapffel]], Chairman of the Committee of Mechanics. Models of both devices were placed in the Society's repository.<ref name='Mandrel'/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=NO. II. Elliptograph|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1843|volume=LIV|pages=8–13|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326879/41326879#page/n1/mode/2up|access-date=13 November 2015|location=Jstor}}</ref> The ellipsograph and a diagrammatic model in wood of Hick's [[Steam engine#Rotary steam engines|rotary engine]] produced in 1843 are held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] collection.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hick |first1=John |title=Ellipsograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton |url=https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/objects/co60100/ellipsograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolton |website=Science Museum Group |access-date=4 September 2025 |location=UK |date=1840}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last1=Hick |first1=John | title=Diagrammatic model in wood of Hick's rotary engine | url=https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/objects/co51098/diagrammatic-model-in-wood-of-hicks-rotary-engine | website=Science Museum Group | location=UK |access-date=5 September 2024 |date=1843}}</ref> Following Benjamin Hick's sudden death in September 1842, John and his youngest brother William continued with the family business, while Benjamin Jr remained with [[George Forrester and Company]].
During 1842, Hick was awarded a second silver medal by the Society of Arts for his invention of an [[Ellipsograph]]; conceived in 1840,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Elliptograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton|url=https://collection.sciencemuseum.org.uk/objects/co60100/elliptograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolto-curve-drawing-instruments-ellipsographs|website=Science Museum Group|access-date=10 November 2016|date=1840}}</ref> the device provided a simple and accurate solution for the drawing ''[[ellipse|ellipsoid forms]]'' of various proportions. Hick received further praise from [[James Nasmyth]], [[William Fairbairn]], [[Joseph Whitworth]], and amongst others, [[Charles Holtzapffel]], Chairman of the Committee of Mechanics. Models of both devices were placed in the Society's repository.<ref name='Mandrel'/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=NO. II. Elliptograph|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1843|volume=LIV|pages=8–13|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326879/41326879#page/n1/mode/2up|access-date=13 November 2015|location=Jstor}}</ref> The ellipsograph and a diagrammatic model in wood of Hick's [[Steam engine#Rotary steam engines|rotary engine]] produced in 1843 are held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] collection.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hick |first1=John |title=Ellipsograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton |url=https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/objects/co60100/ellipsograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolton |website=Science Museum Group |access-date=4 September 2025 |location=UK |date=1840}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last1=Hick |first1=John | title=Diagrammatic model in wood of Hick's rotary engine | url=https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/objects/co51098/diagrammatic-model-in-wood-of-hicks-rotary-engine | website=Science Museum Group | location=UK |access-date=5 September 2024 |date=1843}}</ref>


John's brother Benjamin also presented to the Society of Arts; in 1844, he outlined his design published in October 1843, for an improved double-cylinder [[marine steam engine]]. <ref>{{cite journal|last=Unknown|title=Direct Action Engines|journal=The Civil Engineer and Architect's Journal. Scientific and Railway Gazette.|date=October 1843|volume=6|pages=366–367|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VL1BAAAAYAAJ&q=benjamin+hick+george+forrester&pg=PA367|access-date=27 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hick|first=Benjamin|title=On George Forrester and Co.s Improved Double-Cylinder Marine Engine, Invented by B. HIck, Esq. By B. Hick (of the above firm), Engineer|journal=Transactions of the Society of Arts|date=20 March 1844|volume= 54–55|pages=136–143|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hM4-AQAAMAAJ&q=benjamin+hick+george+forrester&pg=RA1-PA136|access-date=26 March 2014}}</ref> John was then elected a [[Town councillor]] on 1 November, serving three terms of three years until 1853<ref name='Redfern'/> however, their youngest brother William, who oversaw the installation of their father's advanced 2-cyclinder beam engine at [[Temple Works]] in 1841, died of [[Tuberculosis]] about 3 weeks later on 23 November 1844; tragically Benjamin's death followed in [[Southport]] on 20 November 1845.<ref name='Benjamin'/> With his eldest sister Mary in a position to help, John became senior partner in the family business with his brother-in-law John Hargreaves Jr during 1845; he joined the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] and [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] in the same year.<ref name=Debretts/><ref name='obit'/><ref name='obit2'/><ref name='obit3'/><ref>{{cite journal |title=The Council and Officers for the 113th Session, 1866-7 |journal=The Journal of the Society of Arts |date=16 November 1866 |volume=14 |issue=730 |pages=3, 16 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/41336069.pdf |access-date=28 August 2024 |publisher=Royal Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce |location=JSTOR |jstor=41336069 |language=English}}</ref> The firm would eventually become Hick, Hargreaves & Co.
Following their father's sudden death in September 1842, John and his youngest brother William continued with the family business, while brother Benjamin remained with [[George Forrester and Company]]. Benjamin also presented to the Society of Arts; in 1844, he outlined his design published in October 1843, for an improved double-cylinder [[marine steam engine]]. <ref>{{cite journal|last=Unknown|title=Direct Action Engines|journal=The Civil Engineer and Architect's Journal. Scientific and Railway Gazette.|date=October 1843|volume=6|pages=366–367|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VL1BAAAAYAAJ&q=benjamin+hick+george+forrester&pg=PA367|access-date=27 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hick|first=Benjamin|title=On George Forrester and Co.s Improved Double-Cylinder Marine Engine, Invented by B. HIck, Esq. By B. Hick (of the above firm), Engineer|journal=Transactions of the Society of Arts|date=20 March 1844|volume= 54–55|pages=136–143|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hM4-AQAAMAAJ&q=benjamin+hick+george+forrester&pg=RA1-PA136|access-date=26 March 2014}}</ref> John was then elected a [[Town councillor]] on 1 November, serving three terms of three years until 1853<ref name='Redfern'/> however, their youngest brother William, who oversaw the installation of their father's advanced 2-cyclinder beam engine at [[Temple Works]] in 1841, died of [[Tuberculosis]] about 3 weeks later on 23 November 1844; tragically Benjamin's death followed in [[Southport]] on 20 November 1845.<ref name='Benjamin'/> With his eldest sister Mary in a position to help, John became senior partner in the family business with his brother-in-law John Hargreaves Jr during 1845; he joined the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] and [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] in the same year.<ref name=Debretts/><ref name='obit'/><ref name='obit2'/><ref name='obit3'/><ref>{{cite journal |title=The Council and Officers for the 113th Session, 1866-7 |journal=The Journal of the Society of Arts |date=16 November 1866 |volume=14 |issue=730 |pages=3, 16 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/41336069.pdf |access-date=28 August 2024 |publisher=Royal Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce |location=JSTOR |jstor=41336069 |language=English}}</ref> The firm would eventually become Hick, Hargreaves & Co.


About 1845 John produced a 1:12 [[Scale (ratio)|scale]] model of a high pressure two-cylinder design for a horizontal [[saw-mill]] engine, now displayed at the [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers]];<ref>{{cite web |last1=HIck |first1=John |title=High pressure two-cylinder horizontal Hick saw-mill engine |url=http://vads.ac.uk/large.php?uid=217195&sos=0 |website=Institute of Mechanical Engineers |publisher=vads |access-date=6 September 2024 |location=UK |date=1845|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072222/http://vads.ac.uk/large.php?uid=217195&sos=0 |archive-date=4 March 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Model Hick saw-mill engine, c.1845 |url=https://archivecat.imeche.org/records/IME/13/7/12 |website=Institute of Mechanical Engineers |access-date=6 September 2024 |date=2021}}</ref> he was a founder and member from 1847 until 1852,<ref name='obit2'/> and contributed a paper to the institute in 1849 on a friction [[clutch]] ''for connecting and disconnecting the driving power with shafts and machinery''.<ref name='obit2'/> A B. Hick and Son, 1:12 scale [[patent model]] of ''disconnecting apparatus, for [[screw propeller]]s'', c. 1855 is held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] [[Marine propulsion|marine engines]] collection.<ref>{{cite web|last1=B. Hick & Son|title=Model of disconnecting apparatus, for screw propellers.|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?type=related&kv=39375&t=objects|website=Science Museum Group|access-date=11 November 2016|date=c. 1855}}</ref>
About 1845 John produced a 1:12 [[Scale (ratio)|scale]] model of a high pressure two-cylinder design for a horizontal [[saw-mill]] engine, now displayed at the [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers]];<ref>{{cite web |last1=HIck |first1=John |title=High pressure two-cylinder horizontal Hick saw-mill engine |url=http://vads.ac.uk/large.php?uid=217195&sos=0 |website=Institute of Mechanical Engineers |publisher=vads |access-date=6 September 2024 |location=UK |date=1845|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072222/http://vads.ac.uk/large.php?uid=217195&sos=0 |archive-date=4 March 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Model Hick saw-mill engine, c.1845 |url=https://archivecat.imeche.org/records/IME/13/7/12 |website=Institute of Mechanical Engineers |access-date=6 September 2024 |date=2021}}</ref> he was a founder and member from 1847 until 1852,<ref name='obit2'/> and contributed a paper to the institute in 1849 on a friction [[clutch]] ''for connecting and disconnecting the driving power with shafts and machinery''.<ref name='obit2'/> A B. Hick and Son, 1:12 scale [[patent model]] of ''disconnecting apparatus, for [[screw propeller]]s'', c. 1855 is held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] [[Marine propulsion|marine engines]] collection.<ref>{{cite web|last1=B. Hick & Son|title=Model of disconnecting apparatus, for screw propellers.|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?type=related&kv=39375&t=objects|website=Science Museum Group|access-date=11 November 2016|date=c. 1855}}</ref>

source_payload.html:
Health: WP:EUPHEMISM

← Previous revision Revision as of 19:47, 7 February 2026
Line 53: Line 53:
Arnold was a recovering [[alcoholic]] who stopped drinking in 2016.<ref name="voket">{{cite news |last=Voket |first=John |date=May 12, 2016 |title=Concert Preview: 3 Doors Down Singer Celebrating Sobriety, New Album, Tour |publisher=The Newtown Bee |url=https://www.newtownbee.com/3-doors-down-singer-celebrating-sobriety-new-album-tour/ |url-status=dead |access-date=July 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190621191851/https://www.newtownbee.com/3-doors-down-singer-celebrating-sobriety-new-album-tour/ |archive-date=June 21, 2019}}</ref>
Arnold was a recovering [[alcoholic]] who stopped drinking in 2016.<ref name="voket">{{cite news |last=Voket |first=John |date=May 12, 2016 |title=Concert Preview: 3 Doors Down Singer Celebrating Sobriety, New Album, Tour |publisher=The Newtown Bee |url=https://www.newtownbee.com/3-doors-down-singer-celebrating-sobriety-new-album-tour/ |url-status=dead |access-date=July 18, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190621191851/https://www.newtownbee.com/3-doors-down-singer-celebrating-sobriety-new-album-tour/ |archive-date=June 21, 2019}}</ref>


On May 7, 2025, Arnold announced that he had been diagnosed with Stage IV clear [[Renal cell carcinoma|renal cell carcinoma]], which had [[metastasized]] to his lung. Despite the severity of the diagnosis, Arnold stated that he had "no fear".<ref name="auto2" /> Arnold passed away at the age of 47 on February 7, 2026.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Higgins |first=David M. II |date=February 7, 2026 |title=3 Doors Down Frontman Brad Arnold Dies at 47 After Battle with Stage 4 Cancer |url=https://southernmarylandchronicle.com/2026/02/07/3-doors-down-frontman-brad-arnold-dies-at-47-after-battle-with-stage-4-cancer/ |access-date=February 7, 2026 |website=The Southern Maryland Chronicle |language=en-US}}</ref>
On May 7, 2025, Arnold announced that he had been diagnosed with Stage IV clear [[Renal cell carcinoma|renal cell carcinoma]], which had [[metastasized]] to his lung. Despite the severity of the diagnosis, Arnold stated that he had "no fear".<ref name="auto2" /> Arnold died at the age of 47 on February 7, 2026.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Higgins |first=David M. II |date=February 7, 2026 |title=3 Doors Down Frontman Brad Arnold Dies at 47 After Battle with Stage 4 Cancer |url=https://southernmarylandchronicle.com/2026/02/07/3-doors-down-frontman-brad-arnold-dies-at-47-after-battle-with-stage-4-cancer/ |access-date=February 7, 2026 |website=The Southern Maryland Chronicle |language=en-US}}</ref>

[[Wikipedia:Welcoming committee/Welcome to Wikipedia|Welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/Oneuppr|your contributions]] to this free encyclopedia. If you decide that you need help, check out ''Getting Help'' below, ask me on [[User talk:XLinkBot|my talk page]], or place '''{{tl|helpme}}''' on your talk page and ask your question there. source_payload.html:
Message re. Eight Crazy Nights (HG) (3.4.14)

New page

== February 2026 ==

[[File:Information.svg|25px|alt=Information icon]] Hello, I'm [[User:Adakiko|Adakiko]], and [[Help:Getting started|welcome to Wikipedia]]. I appreciate [[Special:Contributions/~2025-35435-49|your contributions]], but in one of your recent edits to [[:Eight Crazy Nights]], it appears that you added [[Wikipedia:No original research|original research]], which is against Wikipedia's policies. Original research refers to material—such as facts, allegations, ideas, and personal experiences—for which no reliable, published sources exist; it also encompasses [[Wikipedia:No original research#Synthesis of published material that advances a position|combining published sources]] in a way to imply something that none of them explicitly say. Please be prepared to cite a [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable source]] for all of your contributions. You can have a look at the [[Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1|tutorial on citing sources]]. Thank you.<!-- Template:uw-nor1 --> [[User:Adakiko|Adakiko]] ([[User talk:Adakiko|talk]]) 19:47, 7 February 2026 (UTC)

The title is taken from a line in Sandler's "[[The Chanukah Song]]" that compares the gift-giving traditions of [[Christmas]] and Hanukkah: "Instead of one day of presents, we get eight crazy nights!" A new version of the song plays over the film's closing credits.
The title is taken from a line in Sandler's "[[The Chanukah Song]]" that compares the gift-giving traditions of [[Christmas]] and Hanukkah: "Instead of one day of presents, we get eight crazy nights!" A new version of the song plays over the film's closing credits.


''Eight Crazy Nights'' was released in the United States on November 27, 2002, by [[Sony Pictures Releasing]]. It received negative reviews and grossed $23.8 million. Nowadays, it has become a cult following.

source_payload.html:
John W. Tibbatts removed from category, this page is included within other pages

← Previous revision Revision as of 19:47, 7 February 2026
Line 38: Line 38:
Tibbatts represented [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell County]] in the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]] from 1827 to 1829 and from 1841 to 1843.<ref name="warrick"/><ref name="courier">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-courier-journal-john-w-tibbatts/190760068/ |title=John W. Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts represented [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell County]] in the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]] from 1827 to 1829 and from 1841 to 1843.<ref name="warrick"/><ref name="courier">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-courier-journal-john-w-tibbatts/190760068/ |title=John W. Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>

In May 1844, Tibbatts advocated for the annexation of Texas. His speech stated that the expansion into Texas would be "favorable to the gradual, peaceable, and constitutional abolition of slavery on this continent. The African race... will gradually recede from the North, which is uncongenial to their natures... and become blended with the mixed population of Mexico".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/manifestdestinye0000alla/page/60/mode/2up |title=Manifest Destiny and Expansionism in the 1840's |last=Kownslar |first=Allan O. |publisher=D. C. Heath and Company |year=1967 |pages=61–63 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was appointed by President [[James K. Polk]] as a colonel of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)|16th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/> He served from March 1847 to August 1848.<ref name="courier"/> The regiment were engaged in the campaign to the [[Rio Grande]]. They were part of the guard of [[Monterrey]]. Tibbatts was appointed as the civil military governor of Monterrey by General [[Zachary Taylor]] on September 1, 1847.<ref name="warrick"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/tri-weekly-commonwealth-we-are-indebted/190759926/ |title=We are indebted to our friend John W. Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>
Tibbatts was appointed by President [[James K. Polk]] as a colonel of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)|16th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/> He served from March 1847 to August 1848.<ref name="courier"/> The regiment were engaged in the campaign to the [[Rio Grande]]. They were part of the guard of [[Monterrey]]. Tibbatts was appointed as the civil military governor of Monterrey by General [[Zachary Taylor]] on September 1, 1847.<ref name="warrick"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/tri-weekly-commonwealth-we-are-indebted/190759926/ |title=We are indebted to our friend John W. Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>


==Personal life==
==Personal life==
Tibbatts married Ann Taylor, a daughter of Keturah (née Moss) and General [[James Taylor Jr. (banker)|James Taylor]], of Newport in 1824 or 1825.<ref name="sentinel"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/lexington-weekly-press-married-10-jan-1/190760578/ |title=Married |date=1825-01-10 |newspaper=Lexington Weekly Press |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mossofvirginiaco00wulf/mode/2up |title=Moss of Virginia |publisher=Dorothy Ford Wulfeck |year=1962 |page=3 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Tibbatts had at least two daughters, Susan and Keturah Moss.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-coming-home-to-final/190760319/ |title="Coming Home" to Final Rest |date=1963-12-10 |newspaper=The Kentucky Post |page=1 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref name="hodge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-gen-hodges-remains-w/190760203/ |title=Gen. Hodge's Remains Were Brought to Newport |date=1903-01-01 |newspaper=Kentucky Post |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> His daughter Keturah Moss married Kentucky politician and Confederate general [[George Baird Hodge]].<ref name="hodge"/>
Tibbatts married Ann Wilkinson Taylor, a daughter of Keturah (née Moss) and General [[James Taylor Jr. (banker)|James Taylor]], of Newport in 1824 or 1825.<ref name="sentinel"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/lexington-weekly-press-married-10-jan-1/190760578/ |title=Married |date=1825-01-10 |newspaper=Lexington Weekly Press |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mossofvirginiaco00wulf/mode/2up |title=Moss of Virginia |publisher=Dorothy Ford Wulfeck |year=1962 |page=3 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/papersofandrewja0008jack/page/272/mode/2up |title=The Papers of Andrew Jackson |volume=8 |editor-last1=Feller |editor-first1=Daniel |editor-last2=Coens |editor-first2=Thomas |editor-last3=Moss |editor-first3=Laura-Eve |publisher=The University of Tennessee Press |year=1980 |page=272 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}</ref> Tibbatts had at least two daughters, Susan and Keturah Moss.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-coming-home-to-final/190760319/ |title="Coming Home" to Final Rest |date=1963-12-10 |newspaper=The Kentucky Post |page=1 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref name="hodge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-gen-hodges-remains-w/190760203/ |title=Gen. Hodge's Remains Were Brought to Newport |date=1903-01-01 |newspaper=Kentucky Post |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> His daughter Keturah Moss married Kentucky politician and Confederate general [[George Baird Hodge]].<ref name="hodge"/>


Tibbatts died of cholera on July 5, 1852, at his home in Newport. He was buried in Evergreen Cemetery.<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/>

Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts represented [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell County]] in the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]] from 1827 to 1829 and from 1841 to 1843.<ref name="warrick"/><ref name="courier">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-courier-journal-john-w-tibbatts/190760068/ |title=John W. Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>

In May 1844, Tibbatts advocated for the annexation of Texas. His speech stated that the expansion into Texas would be "favorable to the gradual, peaceable, and constitutional abolition of slavery on this continent. The African race... will gradually recede from the North, which is uncongenial to their natures... and become blended with the mixed population of Mexico".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/manifestdestinye0000alla/page/60/mode/2up |title=Manifest Destiny and Expansionism in the 1840's |last=Kownslar |first=Allan O. |publisher=D. C. Heath and Company |year=1967 |pages=61–63 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was appointed by President [[James K. Polk]] as a colonel of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)|16th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/> He served from March 1847 to August 1848.<ref name="courier"/> The regiment were engaged in the campaign to the [[Rio Grande]]. They were part of the guard of [[Monterrey]]. Tibbatts was appointed as the civil military governor of Monterrey by General [[Zachary Taylor]] on September 1, 1847.<ref name="warrick"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/tri-weekly-commonwealth-we-are-indebted/190759926/ |title=We are indebted to our friend John W. Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>
Tibbatts was appointed by President [[James K. Polk]] as a colonel of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)|16th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/> He served from March 1847 to August 1848.<ref name="courier"/> The regiment were engaged in the campaign to the [[Rio Grande]]. They were part of the guard of [[Monterrey]]. Tibbatts was appointed as the civil military governor of Monterrey by General [[Zachary Taylor]] on September 1, 1847.<ref name="warrick"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/tri-weekly-commonwealth-we-are-indebted/190759926/ |title=We are indebted to our friend John W. Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>


==Personal life==
==Personal life==
Tibbatts married Ann Taylor, a daughter of Keturah (née Moss) and General [[James Taylor Jr. (banker)|James Taylor]], of Newport in 1824 or 1825.<ref name="sentinel"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/lexington-weekly-press-married-10-jan-1/190760578/ |title=Married |date=1825-01-10 |newspaper=Lexington Weekly Press |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mossofvirginiaco00wulf/mode/2up |title=Moss of Virginia |publisher=Dorothy Ford Wulfeck |year=1962 |page=3 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Tibbatts had at least two daughters, Susan and Keturah Moss.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-coming-home-to-final/190760319/ |title="Coming Home" to Final Rest |date=1963-12-10 |newspaper=The Kentucky Post |page=1 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref name="hodge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-gen-hodges-remains-w/190760203/ |title=Gen. Hodge's Remains Were Brought to Newport |date=1903-01-01 |newspaper=Kentucky Post |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> His daughter Keturah Moss married Kentucky politician and Confederate general [[George Baird Hodge]].<ref name="hodge"/>
Tibbatts married Ann Wilkinson Taylor, a daughter of Keturah (née Moss) and General [[James Taylor Jr. (banker)|James Taylor]], of Newport in 1824 or 1825.<ref name="sentinel"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/lexington-weekly-press-married-10-jan-1/190760578/ |title=Married |date=1825-01-10 |newspaper=Lexington Weekly Press |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mossofvirginiaco00wulf/mode/2up |title=Moss of Virginia |publisher=Dorothy Ford Wulfeck |year=1962 |page=3 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/papersofandrewja0008jack/page/272/mode/2up |title=The Papers of Andrew Jackson |volume=8 |editor-last1=Feller |editor-first1=Daniel |editor-last2=Coens |editor-first2=Thomas |editor-last3=Moss |editor-first3=Laura-Eve |publisher=The University of Tennessee Press |year=1980 |page=272 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}</ref> Tibbatts had at least two daughters, Susan and Keturah Moss.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-coming-home-to-final/190760319/ |title="Coming Home" to Final Rest |date=1963-12-10 |newspaper=The Kentucky Post |page=1 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref name="hodge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-gen-hodges-remains-w/190760203/ |title=Gen. Hodge's Remains Were Brought to Newport |date=1903-01-01 |newspaper=Kentucky Post |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> His daughter Keturah Moss married Kentucky politician and Confederate general [[George Baird Hodge]].<ref name="hodge"/>


Tibbatts died of cholera on July 5, 1852, at his home in Newport. He was buried in Evergreen Cemetery.<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/>

Tibbatts represented [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell County]] in the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]] from 1827 to 1829 and from 1841 to 1843.<ref name="warrick"/><ref name="courier">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-courier-journal-john-w-tibbatts/190760068/ |title=John W. Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts represented [[Campbell County, Kentucky|Campbell County]] in the [[Kentucky House of Representatives]] from 1827 to 1829 and from 1841 to 1843.<ref name="warrick"/><ref name="courier">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-courier-journal-john-w-tibbatts/190760068/ |title=John W. Tibbatts... |date=1883-04-01 |newspaper=[[Courier Journal]] |page=6 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In 1836, he was president of a committee in Campbell County to assess the practicability of building a railroad from Newport to Lexington as part of the [[Cincinnati and Charleston Railroad]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/historyofcampbel00jone/page/12/mode/2up |title=History of Campbell County |last=Jones |first=Mary Keturah |year=1876 |pages=11–12 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>
Tibbatts was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], defeating William K. Wall in 1842. He represented the [[Kentucky's 10th congressional district|10th district]] in that body from 1843 to 1847. He was defeated for re-election in 1847 by [[John P. Gaines]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="courier"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-lexington-press-election-news-7-aug/190759823/ |title=Election News |date=1847-08-07 |newspaper=Observer & Reporter |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> In his campaign against his relative and Whig candidate [[William Wright Southgate]], they canvassed the district together and played music for people, Tibbatts playing the fiddle left-handed. According to one story on the campaign trail, Southgate insinuated to the public that Tibbatts could play fiddle the fiddle better with his right hand, but only to "nice people" and not to "ignorant people".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/benchbarcomplete00bige/page/300/mode/2up |title=Bench and Bar: A Complete Digest of the Wit, Humor, Asperities, and Amenities of the Law |last=Bigelow |first=L. J. |publisher=Harper & Brothers |year=1867 |pages=300–302 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>

In May 1844, Tibbatts advocated for the annexation of Texas. His speech stated that the expansion into Texas would be "favorable to the gradual, peaceable, and constitutional abolition of slavery on this continent. The African race... will gradually recede from the North, which is uncongenial to their natures... and become blended with the mixed population of Mexico".<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/manifestdestinye0000alla/page/60/mode/2up |title=Manifest Destiny and Expansionism in the 1840's |last=Kownslar |first=Allan O. |publisher=D. C. Heath and Company |year=1967 |pages=61–63 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}</ref> In December 1844, he proposed the annexation of Texas as a state and that they should receive protection from the Union on the House floor.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/memoirsofjohnqui12adam/page/134/mode/2up |title=Memoirs of John Quincy Adams |editor=[[Charles Francis Adams|Adams, Charles Francis]] |volume=12 |publisher=J. B. Lippincott & Co. |year=1877 |page=135 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> He unsuccessfully proposed in February 1846 a boundary settlement with Mexico along the Sierra Madre Mountains. When war came he supported the Polk administration's war policy.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mexicanwar0000kjac/page/362/mode/2up |title=The Mexican War, 1846–1848 |last=Bauer |first=K. Jack |publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company, Inc. and Collier Macmillan Publishers |year=1974 |page=363 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref>


Tibbatts was appointed by President [[James K. Polk]] as a colonel of the [[16th Infantry Regiment (United States)|16th Infantry Regiment]] in the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref name="bio"/><ref name="warrick"/> He served from March 1847 to August 1848.<ref name="courier"/> The regiment were engaged in the campaign to the [[Rio Grande]]. They were part of the guard of [[Monterrey]]. Tibbatts was appointed as the civil military governor of Monterrey by General [[Zachary Taylor]] on September 1, 1847.<ref name="warrick"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/tri-weekly-commonwealth-we-are-indebted/190759926/ |title=We are indebted to our friend John W. Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>

Tibbatts... |date=1847-10-12 |newspaper=Frankfort |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Following the war, he resumed practicing law in Newport.<ref name="bio"/>

==Personal life==
Tibbatts married Ann Taylor, a daughter of Keturah (née Moss) and General [[James Taylor Jr. (banker)|James Taylor]], of Newport in 1824 or 1825.<ref name="sentinel"/><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/lexington-weekly-press-married-10-jan-1/190760578/ |title=Married |date=1825-01-10 |newspaper=Lexington Weekly Press |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/mossofvirginiaco00wulf/mode/2up |title=Moss of Virginia |publisher=Dorothy Ford Wulfeck |year=1962 |page=3 |via=[[Archive.org]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> Tibbatts had at least two daughters, Susan and Keturah Moss.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-coming-home-to-final/190760319/ |title="Coming Home" to Final Rest |date=1963-12-10 |newspaper=The Kentucky Post |page=1 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref><ref name="hodge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-kentucky-post-gen-hodges-remains-w/190760203/ |title=Gen. Hodge's Remains Were Brought to Newport |date=1903-01-01 |newspaper=Kentucky Post |page=3 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |access-date=2026-02-07}}{{Open access}}</ref> His daughter Keturah Moss married Kentucky politician and Confederate general [[George Baird Hodge]].<ref name="hodge"/>

Line 4: Line 4:
Ian Sean Feinberg was born in [[South Africa]] in 1963 and moved to Israel after completing high school. He attended the Law School of [[Bar-Ilan University|Bar Ilan University]], which he completed with outstanding grades. After his army service he opened a law office in Tel Aviv and, among other things, provided legal representation to commercial interests in Gaza. He also served as the legal counsel for the Gaza offices of Co-operation for Development, a European-funded aid project which makes loans to businessmen.
Ian Sean Feinberg was born in [[South Africa]] in 1963 and moved to Israel after completing high school. He attended the Law School of [[Bar-Ilan University|Bar Ilan University]], which he completed with outstanding grades. After his army service he opened a law office in Tel Aviv and, among other things, provided legal representation to commercial interests in Gaza. He also served as the legal counsel for the Gaza offices of Co-operation for Development, a European-funded aid project which makes loans to businessmen.


When murdered he left a widow, Ofra, three small children, parents and siblings.<ref>{{Cite web |title=איין שון פיינברג ז'{{'}}ל |url=https://laad.btl.gov.il/Web/He/TerrorVictims/Page/Default.aspx?ID=38224 |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20230406103109/https://laad.btl.gov.il/Web/He/TerrorVictims/Page/Default.aspx?ID=38224 |archive-date=2023-04-06 |access-date=2025-09-08 |website=laad.btl.gov.il |language=he}}</ref>

=== Critical response ===
=== Critical response ===
In previews for the PC version of the game, journalists compared the game to other racing games like ''[[Re-Volt]]'', ''Trackmania'', and ''Micro Machines''.<ref name=":26" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite web |last=Altenheimer |first=Andreas |date=2005-10-18 |title=Mad Tracks - Preview |url=https://www.gameswelt.de/mad-tracks/preview/mad-tracks-871 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20251011211944/https://www.gameswelt.de/mad-tracks/preview/mad-tracks-871 |archive-date=2025-10-11 |access-date=2025-12-08 |website=Gameswelt |language=de-de}}</ref> Both Andreas Altenheimer of ''Gameswelt'' and [[Jeuxvideo.com|''JeuxVideo'']] praised the gameplay, premise and its variety of both minigames and racing tracks.<ref name=":27" /><ref name=":14" /> With the latter expressing that "The game is strongly reminiscent of ''Re-Volt'' and is very fun to play." as well as praising the efficiency of the physics engine.<ref name=":27" /> Though the former criticised the controls, audio, lack of track editor and graphics, calling the last as "a better [[Shareware|shareware game]]".<ref name=":14" />
For the PC version, Andreas Altenheimer of ''Gameswelt'' criticised the controls, audio, lack of track editor and graphics, calling the last as "a better [[Shareware|shareware game]]".<ref name=":14">{{Cite web |last=Altenheimer |first=Andreas |date=2005-10-18 |title=Mad Tracks - Preview |url=https://www.gameswelt.de/mad-tracks/preview/mad-tracks-871 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20251011211944/https://www.gameswelt.de/mad-tracks/preview/mad-tracks-871 |archive-date=2025-10-11 |access-date=2025-12-08 |website=Gameswelt |language=de-de}}</ref>


For the Xbox 360 version, Jonathan Miller, writing for ''[[IGN]]'', described ''Mad Tracks'' as "a decent racing romp, but you better bring your friends."<ref name="IGN5">{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Jonathan |date=June 1, 2007 |title=Mad Tracks Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2007/06/02/mad-tracks-review |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250222034033/https://www.ign.com/articles/2007/06/02/mad-tracks-review |archivedate=February 22, 2025 |accessdate=February 8, 2025 |website=[[IGN]]}}</ref> Greg Sewart of ''[[GamesRadar+]]'', praised gameplay, variety of the courses ([[game modes]]) and online support, but criticized visuals, confusing early sections of the courses and a small amount of content (in the version's basic form).<ref name="GamesRadar+">{{cite web |last=Sewart |first=Greg |date=June 28, 2007 |title=Mad Tracks - Xbox Live Arcade review |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/mad-tracks-xbox-live-arcade-review/ |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20240806230408/https://www.gamesradar.com/mad-tracks-xbox-live-arcade-review/ |archivedate=August 6, 2024 |accessdate=July 12, 2025 |website=[[GamesRadar+]]}}</ref>
For the Xbox 360 version, Jonathan Miller, writing for ''[[IGN]]'', described ''Mad Tracks'' as "a decent racing romp, but you better bring your friends."<ref name="IGN5">{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Jonathan |date=June 1, 2007 |title=Mad Tracks Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2007/06/02/mad-tracks-review |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20250222034033/https://www.ign.com/articles/2007/06/02/mad-tracks-review |archivedate=February 22, 2025 |accessdate=February 8, 2025 |website=[[IGN]]}}</ref> Greg Sewart of ''[[GamesRadar+]]'', praised gameplay, variety of the courses ([[game modes]]) and online support, but criticized visuals, confusing early sections of the courses and a small amount of content (in the version's basic form).<ref name="GamesRadar+">{{cite web |last=Sewart |first=Greg |date=June 28, 2007 |title=Mad Tracks - Xbox Live Arcade review |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/mad-tracks-xbox-live-arcade-review/ |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20240806230408/https://www.gamesradar.com/mad-tracks-xbox-live-arcade-review/ |archivedate=August 6, 2024 |accessdate=July 12, 2025 |website=[[GamesRadar+]]}}</ref>

source_payload.html:
Structure and fabric

← Previous revision Revision as of 19:47, 7 February 2026
Line 38: Line 38:
The church is constructed of slatestone rubble with greenstone and sandstone dressings and slate roofs. The simple plan comprises a combined nave and chancel with a south aisle, north transept, and vestry, together with two west towers and a south-west porch between them. Both towers have three stages with embattled parapets. The south-west tower includes a clock dated 1781, while the north-west tower rises to an octagonal upper stage.<ref name="Historic England" />
The church is constructed of slatestone rubble with greenstone and sandstone dressings and slate roofs. The simple plan comprises a combined nave and chancel with a south aisle, north transept, and vestry, together with two west towers and a south-west porch between them. Both towers have three stages with embattled parapets. The south-west tower includes a clock dated 1781, while the north-west tower rises to an octagonal upper stage.<ref name="Historic England" />


The south aisle, of four bays, has weathered buttresses and four-light Perpendicular windows beneath four-centred arches. The chancel east window is of five lights with Perpendicular tracery and a transom. Other openings include Norman and later medieval doorways, hood-moulded arches, and carved details such as quatrefoils and gargoyles.<ref name="Historic England" />
The south aisle, of four bays, has weathered buttresses and four-light Perpendicular windows beneath four-centred arches. The chancel east window has five lights with Perpendicular tracery and a transom, and other openings include Norman and later medieval doorways with hood-moulded arches and carved detail.<ref name="Historic England" />


Some of the original [[Norman architecture|Norman features]] remain, including the large arched western doorway which is particularly ornate and is carved from [[elvan]] quarried at [[Landrake]].<ref>Sedding, Edmund H. (1909) ''Norman Architecture in Cornwall: a handbook to old ecclesiastical architecture''. London: Ward & Co.; pp. 135-152</ref>
Some of the original [[Norman architecture|Norman features]] remain, including the large arched western doorway which is particularly ornate and is carved from [[elvan]] quarried at [[Landrake]].<ref>Sedding, Edmund H. (1909) ''Norman Architecture in Cornwall: a handbook to old ecclesiastical architecture''. London: Ward & Co.; pp. 135-152</ref>

'''Fethi Ghares''' ({{Langx|ar|فتحي غراس|Fatḥī Ghirās}}; born 20 July 1973) is an Algerian politician. A member of the [[Democratic and Social Movement (Algeria)|Democratic and Social Movement]], which was banned by Algerian authorities in 2023, he has been arrested and imprisoned several times for his activism, particularly his criticisms of the [[President of Algeria]], [[Abdelmadjid Tebboune]].

== Biography ==
Ghares was born in [[Algiers]]. He joined the Democratic and Social Movement upon its formation in 1998, while studying at the agricultural institute in [[Mostaganem]]. He was a member of the party's national bureau until 2013, when he became its official spokesperson.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Abane |first=Meziane |date=20 July 2018 |title=Avec moi, toutes les injustices issues de la décennie noire seront réparées |url=https://www.elwatan.com/edition/actualite/avec-moi-toutes-les-injustices-issues-de-la-decennie-noire-seront-reparees-20-07-2018 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.elwatan.com%2Fedition%2Factualite%2Favec-moi-toutes-les-injustices-issues-de-la-decennie-noire-seront-reparees-20-07-2018#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=31 March 2019 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[El Watan]] |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Guenanfa |first=Hadjer |date=2 May 2018 |title=Entretien avec Fethi Ghares, premier candidat déclaré à la présidentielle de 2019 |url=https://www.tsa-algerie.com/entretien-avec-fethi-ghares-premier-candidat-declare-a-la-presidentielle-de-2019/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tsa-algerie.com%2Fentretien-avec-fethi-ghares-premier-candidat-declare-a-la-presidentielle-de-2019%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=21 February 2025 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=TSA Algérie |language=fr}}</ref> Ghares has described the French West Indian political philosopher [[Frantz Fanon]] as among his biggest influences. In May 2018, he publicly asserted that he supported freedom of conscience, and called for the separation of politics and religion to be enshrined in the [[Constitution of Algeria|Algerian constitution]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hamouchene |first=Hamza |date=12 June 2021 |title=In Algeria’s Freedom Struggle, the Spirit of Frantz Fanon Is Still Alive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250916232437/https://jacobin.com/2021/12/algeria-frantz-fanon-anti-colonialism-france-oppression-extractivism |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250916232437/https://jacobin.com/2021/12/algeria-frantz-fanon-anti-colonialism-france-oppression-extractivism |archive-date=16 September 2025 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Jacobin (magazine)|Jacobin]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Alilat |first=Farid |date=28 May 2018 |title=Algérie : Fethi Ghares, l'homme qui veut dépoussiérer la gauche |url=https://www.jeuneafrique.com/mag/560959/politique/algerie-fethi-ghares-lhomme-qui-veut-depoussierer-la-gauche/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jeuneafrique.com%2Fmag%2F560959%2Fpolitique%2Falgerie-fethi-ghares-lhomme-qui-veut-depoussierer-la-gauche%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=26 October 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |language=fr}}</ref>

Ghares is married to Messaouda Cheballah, a member of the executive secretariat of the Democratic and Social Movement.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/media_2026/01/WR2026%20web_2.pdf |title=World Report 2026 |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |year=2026 |isbn=979-8-88708-274-5 |location=New York City |language=en |access-date=7 February 2026 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20260204233950/https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/media_2026/01/WR2026%20web_2.pdf |archive-date=4 February 2026 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Ghares announced himself as the Democratic and Social Movement candidate for the [[2019 Algerian presidential election]], though did not submit an official dossier of his candidacy.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Moussaoui |first=Rosa |date=16 November 2018 |title=Maghreb. Fethi Ghares, la promesse d'une Algérie émancipée |url=https://www.humanite.fr/monde/maghreb-fethi-ghares-la-promesse-dune-algerie-emancipee-663739 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.humanite.fr%2Fmaghreb-fethi-ghares-la-promesse-dune-algerie-emancipee-663739#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=26 October 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[L'Humanité]] |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=21 January 2019 |title=Présidentielle : Le candidat du MDS Fethi Ghares entame les démarches administratives |url=https://www.elwatan.com/edition/actualite/presidentielle-le-candidat-du-mds-fethi-ghares-entame-les-demarches-administratives-21-01-2019 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.elwatan.com%2Fedition%2Factualite%2Fpresidentielle-le-candidat-du-mds-fethi-ghares-entame-les-demarches-administratives-21-01-2019#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=23 May 2019 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[El Watan]] |language=fr}}</ref> Following the outbreak of the [[Hirak (Algeria)|Hirak]] protests, he renounced his candidacy and instead called for an end to the current Algerian political system, to be replaced with a presidium comprised of four or five independent candidates and the installation of a non-partisan transitional government.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ouahib |first=Sofia |date=24 May 2019 |title=Après les propos d’Ahmed Gaïd Salah sur le maintien de l’élection présidentielle : La riposte du peuple |url=https://www.elwatan.com/edition/actualite/la-riposte-du-peuple-24-05-2019 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.elwatan.com%2Fedition%2Factualite%2Fla-riposte-du-peuple-24-05-2019#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=26 May 2019 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[El Watan]] |language=fr}}</ref>

In addition to politics, Ghares has also acted in films, including a leading role in ''Révolution Zendj'' by [[Tariq Teguia]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Regnier |first=Isabelle |date=4 March 2015 |title=« Révolution Zendj » : sous la poussière, les braises des soulèvements passés |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2015/03/10/revolution-zendj-sous-la-poussiere-les-braises-des-soulevements-passes_4590750_3476.html |url-status=live |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Monde]] |language=fr}}</ref>

=== 2021 arrest and imprisonment ===
On 30 June 2021, Ghares was arrested at his home in [[Djasr Kasentina]] by plainclothes police officers. The [[National Committee for the Liberation of Detainees]] subsequently issued a press release which alleged that, after initially being taken to a police station, Ghares had been returned to his home in order for a search to take place, before being transported to an unknown location.<ref>{{Cite news |date=30 June 2021 |title=Fethi Ghares, président du MDS, arrêté chez lui (CNLD) |url=https://observalgerie.com/2021/06/30/politique/cnld-fethi-ghares-arrete-police/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.observalgerie.com%2F2021%2F06%2F30%2Fpolitique%2Fcnld-fethi-ghares-arrete-police%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=26 October 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=ObservAlgérie |language=fr}}</ref>

On 1 July 2021, Ghares was ordered into pretrial detention by a judge at a court in [[Hammamet, Algiers|Hammamet]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=1 July 2021 |title=URGENT : Fethi Ghares placé sous mandat de dépôt (CNLD) |url=https://observalgerie.com/2021/07/01/politique/cnld-algerie-fethi-ghares-prison/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.observalgerie.com%2F2021%2F07%2F01%2Fpolitique%2Fcnld-algerie-fethi-ghares-prison%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=11 February 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=ObservAlgérie |language=fr}}</ref> His trial was originally scheduled to begin on 6 December, before being delayed to 12 December.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sankari |first=Lina |date=6 December 2021 |title=Algérie. Fethi Ghares, incarcéré pour ses idées |url=https://www.humanite.fr/algerie-fethi-ghares-incarcere-pour-ses-idees-730102 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.humanite.fr%2Falgerie-fethi-ghares-incarcere-pour-ses-idees-730102#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=13 January 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[L'Humanité]] |language=fr}}</ref> On 9 January 2022, Ghares was sentenced to two years imprisonment on charges of "insulting the President of the Republic", "contempt of a constitutional body", "disseminating publications that could harm the national unity", and "disseminating information that could harm public order". The sentence was criticised by the opposition movement in Algeria.<ref>{{Cite news |date=9 January 2022 |title=Condamnation de Fethi Ghares : les réactions de l'opposition |url=https://www.tsa-algerie.com/condamnation-de-fethi-ghares-les-reactions-de-lopposition/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tsa-algerie.com%2Fcondamnation-de-fethi-ghares-les-reactions-de-lopposition%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=24 March 2022 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=TSA Algérie |language=fr}}</ref>

In March 2022, Ghares' sentence was reduced to six months imprisonment following a successful appeal, which led to his immediate release from prison. He subsequently publicly commented on conditions at [[El Harrach]] Prison, describing it as "medieval" and stating that no one left it "unscathed".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Alilat |first=Farid |date=28 March 2022 |title=Algérie : Fethi Ghares raconte la prison d'El Harrach |url=https://www.jeuneafrique.com/1334057/politique/algerieaf-fethi-ghares-raconte-la-prison-del-harrach/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jeuneafrique.com%2F1334057%2Fpolitique%2Falgerieaf-fethi-ghares-raconte-la-prison-del-harrach%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=9 April 2025 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |language=fr}}</ref>

In February 2023, the Democratic and Social Movement was banned.<ref>{{Cite news |date=29 August 2024 |title=Algérie: l’opposant Fethi Ghares remis en liberté sous contrôle judiciaire |url=https://www.mediapart.fr/journal/fil-dactualites/290824/algerie-l-opposant-fethi-ghares-remis-en-liberte-sous-controle-judiciaire |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fjournal%2Ffil-dactualites%2F290824%2Falgerie-l-opposant-fethi-ghares-remis-en-liberte-sous-controle-judiciaire#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Mediapart]] |language=fr}}</ref>

=== 2024 arrest and imprisonment ===
On 27 August 2024, Ghares was arrested by plainclothes police officers and transported to an unknown location, according to his wife and the National Committee for the Liberation of Detainees. The arrest happened 15 days before the [[2024 Algerian presidential election]], in which Abdelmadjid Tebboune was seeking a second term. Ghares was accused of "disrupting the election".<ref>{{Cite news |date=28 August 2024 |title=Arrestation de l’opposant algérien Fethi Ghares |url=https://www.jeuneafrique.com/1602576/politique/arrestation-de-lopposant-algerien-fethi-ghares/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jeuneafrique.com%2F1602576%2Fpolitique%2Farrestation-de-lopposant-algerien-fethi-ghares%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=K. |first=Yacine |title=Fethi Ghares (coordinateur du MDS) enlevé! |url=https://lematindalgerie.com/fethi-ghares-coordinateur-du-mds-enleve/?amp=1 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Flematindalgerie.com%2Ffethi-ghares-coordinateur-du-mds-enleve%2F%3Famp%3D1#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Matin d'Algérie]] |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=K. |first=Yacine |date=28 August 2024 |title=Fethi Ghares retenu au commissariat central d'Alger |url=https://lematindalgerie.com/fethi-ghares-retenu-au-commissariat-central-dalger/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Flematindalgerie.com%2Ffethi-ghares-retenu-au-commissariat-central-dalger%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Matin d'Algérie]] |language=fr}}</ref>

On 29 August 2024, Ghares was charged with "insulting the president" and "spreading false information and hate speech through social media posts". He was released from custody and placed under judicial supervision.<ref>{{Cite news |date=30 August 2024 |title=L’opposant algérien Fethi Ghares remis en liberté sous contrôle judiciaire |url=https://www.jeuneafrique.com/1603472/politique/lopposant-algerien-fethi-ghares-remis-en-liberte-sous-controle-judiciaire/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jeuneafrique.com%2F1603472%2Fpolitique%2Flopposant-algerien-fethi-ghares-remis-en-liberte-sous-controle-judiciaire%2F#& |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |language=fr}}</ref> In January 2025, Ghares was sentenced to one year in prison and ordered to pay symbolic damages of one [[Algerian dinar|DZD]] to President Tebboune. Ghares' wife received a six-month suspended sentence.<ref>{{Cite news |last=H. |first=Amel |date=19 January 2025 |title=Fethi Ghares et son épouse condamnés à prison ferme pour avoir entravé le processus électoral |url=https://www.algerie360.com/fethi-ghares-et-son-epouse-condamnes-a-prison-ferme-pour-avoir-entrave-le-processus-electoral/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.algerie360.com%2Ffethi-ghares-et-son-epouse-condamnes-a-prison-ferme-pour-avoir-entrave-le-processus-electoral%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=Algerie360 |language=fr}}</ref>

=== 2025 arrest and imprisonment ===
On 29 September 2025, Ghares was arrested for a third time at his home for "insulting the President of the Republic".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ayache |first=Sofiane |date=29 September 2025 |title=Fethi Ghares arrêté par la police |url=https://lematindalgerie.com/fethi-ghares-arrete-par-la-police/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Flematindalgerie.com%2Ffethi-ghares-arrete-par-la-police%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Matin d'Algérie]] |language=fr}}</ref> In October 2025, he was found guilty of "insulting a constituted body" and "disseminating false information undermining public order and national security", and was sentenced to two years imprisonment and a fine of 300, 000 DZD. Ghares remained on provisional release pending the outcome of his appeal of the sentence.<ref>{{Cite news |date=21 October 2025 |title=Fethi Gharès condamné à deux ans de prison ferme |url=https://lematindalgerie.com/fethi-ghares-condamne-a-deux-ans-de-prison-ferme/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Flematindalgerie.com%2Ffethi-ghares-condamne-a-deux-ans-de-prison-ferme%2F#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Matin d'Algérie]] |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=21 October 2025 |title=Algérie : un opposant de gauche condamné à deux ans de prison ferme pour outrage au président |url=https://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/algerie-un-opposant-de-gauche-condamne-a-deux-ans-de-prison-ferme-pour-outrage-au-president-20251021 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/index2.php?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.lefigaro.fr%2Fflash-actu%2Falgerie-un-opposant-de-gauche-condamne-a-deux-ans-de-prison-ferme-pour-outrage-au-president-20251021#federation=archive.wikiwix.com&tab=url |archive-date=7 February 2026 |access-date=7 February 2026 |work=[[Le Figaro]] |language=fr}}</ref>
